description:
Acanthamoeba palestinensis is a free-living, single-celled protist that belongs to the genus Acanthamoeba. It is an amoebozoan, a group of amoeboid organisms that are widely distributed in various environmental habitats, including soil, water, and even the human body.

Acanthamoeba palestinensis is characterized by its ability to form a double-walled cyst stage, which allows the organism to survive in harsh environmental conditions, such as nutrient depletion or desiccation. The trophozoite (active feeding stage) of A. palestinensis is typically 15-45 micrometers in size and exhibits a distinctive feature known as acanthopodia, which are slender, spine-like projections that aid in locomotion and prey capture.

This species was first isolated from soil samples collected in Palestine, hence the specific epithet "palestinensis." Acanthamoeba palestinensis is known to be a potential opportunistic pathogen, capable of causing serious infections in humans, such as Acanthamoeba keratitis, a painful and potentially blinding eye infection, as well as a rare but severe form of encephalitis.

Research on Acanthamoeba palestinensis and other Acanthamoeba species continues to contribute to our understanding of their ecology, evolutionary relationships, and potential impacts on human health, particularly in the context of environmental microbiology and the study of emerging infectious diseases.
